text: [Music]
hello Chicago my name is Eric gger I'm
the managing director of it operations
to the federal Home Loan Bank and we're
not a startup you know we're not a do
com company in fact we were chartered by
Congress in
1932 to provide um to help the home
purchasing Market there are 11 districts
in the homelan banking system Chicago is
one of them and today we're a $70
billion wholesale bank and what that
means is that we loan money to Banks and
we do it for the purpose of supporting
home
purchasing now a few years
ago we were at a bit of a
Crossroads we had some problems with our
traditional data center there were some
physical requirements or some physical
infrastructure upgrades that we had to
do they were going to be very expensive
and they were also going to be very
complicated for us we also were looking
at taking advantage of more commodity
services and Outsourcing that was also
going to be expensive for
us and we really wanted to focus on
changing our model so that we were doing
more it integration and that we were
really looking at our differentiated
solutions to provide better value for
our
members and as we thought about ways to
get us through this we looked at this
thing called the
cloud and the cloud promised better
performance lower
cost uh and particularly at the time it
promised it in some very specific types
of areas and we had two of those first
we had this big analytics prod uh
platform and it was the perfect example
of high performance Computing it
required a lot of calculations to happen
a lot of processors over a very defined
period of time and then they would sit
idle for a very long defined period of
time and that's frustrating it's
frustrating for anyone in infrastructure
because you have to pay for it even when
it's not doing
anything we also had Disaster Recovery I
you know everyone has Disaster Recovery
it's a critical part of your overall
infrastructure but It suffers the same
frustration you have these systems that
you hope you never have to use but they
need to be ready to go at a moment's
notice and you have to pay for them you
have to pay the cooling cost the floor
space in your data center and you have
to keep them updated and managed and
that can be frust
rating but infrastructures of service
looked like a great way for us to get
past a lot of that frustration because
it could take that cost component and it
could diminish it substantially and so
we started a POC a proof of concept on
Amazon um a couple of years
ago now while the technical piece was
running and the proof of concept we
actually had to go back and make sure
that Amazon itself would work for us you
know technology-wise
the infrastructure looked like it was
going to be great but Amazon has all
these certifications all these
accreditations and that's wonderful but
we needed to map them back to our own
internal controls and so we created a
whole framework and then we took all of
Amazon's available data and we mapped
them back in to make sure that we
wouldn't lose anything by moving into
that infrastructures a service model
with these applications that the same
types of controls we expected to have in
our internal data centers or our managed
service data centers we would get
through Amazon and once that framework
was done we reviewed it internally with
our it Ops and our security folks and
our Auditors and we agreed that it would
look good but then we had to cross the
next big hurdle which was security so
the cloud and security it's always a
nervous point for anyone when they're
having a conversation about moving big
portions of their environment in and
everyone who does it has to go through
their own analysis to make sure that it
works for us we actually did the same
thing we did with the rest of our
controls we took all of our security
controls and we mapped them back to the
available services that Amazon had if
there was something that had to change
because we're moving from a traditional
model to a cloud-based model we did an
evaluation of that and we figured out
what those changes would need to look
like we worked with internal and
external vendors to make sure that our
framework was going to look good and
that it would be safe and most
importantly we set up a group of rules
for cloud adoption and for uh and for
Readiness so that when we wanted to go
to production we knew that we had the
things in place that we needed to
have and sure enough after we were done
with all of that it looked like Amazon
in fact was going to be reliable and it
was going to be secure and that we' be
okay to move forward with real
production workloads so we could get out
of that proof of
concept so we went live on Amazon and we
did it with that big analytic platform
we did it with our Disaster Recovery
suite and we began to run in east and
west regions you know we got
geodiversity which was something we
hadn't had before which was very
exciting and as we had more and more
success with more and more apps that we
started looking to run on Amazon our
developers took notice the fast
procurement times the ability to do
quick config changes and they really
liked it so we started to do more and
more development out of the Amazon
platform and an amazing thing happened
you know as we would put systems in
Amazon we saw that they would run faster
and that they were more reliable than
the traditional systems really with no
other change except for that
infrastructure move for other systems we
saw that we could simply make easy fast
configuration changes inside Amazon that
would help those systems run faster be
more reliable and it was a huge win and
the thing
about that type of success is that it
breeds more interest in getting that
kind of
success and so having had started the
proof of concept back in 2013
we begin to immediately build out more
in
Amazon and by about 2014 the very
beginning we had reached about 30% of
our infrastructure
there and suddenly it occurred to us
that we wanted to do more and more and
so we took a little bit of a pause and
we said you know what how do we get
everything
there we formed a team we came up with a
plan and we began that migration process
at the end of
2014 we kicked it into high
gear and by the beginning of 2015 we
were in fact completely in Amazon
overall that process took us about 28
months to go from zero system zero
infrastructure use to 100%
infrastructure use the migration in
Earnest took us about four months to
move from that 30% Plateau up to 100%
Plateau so we completed it in April 2015
and it was a very big success and it
continues to be a big success
operationally we've got a new framework
a new model for doing governance with
these instances and with our cost
management and that makes our operations
team extremely
happy our developers and our project
managers the procurement times have
dropped to almost zero for bringing up
new systems they can do more
experimentation they can do it quicker
that makes them very happy and we've
observed application performance
increases almost across the board which
makes the business very happy but
frankly most of all what makes us happy
what makes our members happy is that our
we saw about a 30% reduction in cost
overall for our infrastructure which is
phenomenal all simply by moving existing
workloads into the Amazon
environment so I'll leave you with this
idea we are an 83 year old organization
and we've seen every technology change
that has happened over those 83 years
and the Amazon change and moving into
infrastructure as a service has been one
of the best ones for the bank and
resulted in some of the best
improvements to our operations model and
to our partners that we've seen so
far thank you very much have a great
rest of your summit
